b1ba30098d4cd4646669fffa1b2fdbca.return:
Scrooge is a central character known for his miserly, cold demeanor and disdain for Christmas festivities. Initially depicted as a tight-fisted and solitary man, he embodies a misanthropic attitude, valuing wealth over generosity and disregarding the joys of the holiday season. Throughout the narrative, Scrooge undergoes a significant transformation, prompted largely by his encounters with supernatural spirits. 

As he reflects on his life and past actions, Scrooge experiences feelings of regret, fear, and nostalgia, particularly as he confronts the consequences of his behavior and observes the joy of others during Christmas. His interactions with these spirits lead him to grapple with moments of horror and disgust, especially when witnessing the neglect of the deceased and the treatment of those around him. This reflective journey deeply impacts his character, softening his heart as he begins to embrace the true spirit of Christmas.

By Christmas Day, Scrooge transforms from a miserly figure into someone filled with joy and good intentions, demonstrating kindness and laughter. He becomes more open and generous, positively responding to the lessons taught by the spirits. Ultimately, Scrooge's journey illustrates a profound character development from an isolated, skeptical individual focused on wealth to a warm-hearted, compassionate person who values human connection and merriment, significantly altering his relationships and outlook on life.
